resource.chars:
19 
2 Ovibos <u>Dawkins<\u> 
[paragraph]5 <u>Measurements<\u> 
The following tables of measurement taken  in inches and 
tenths show at a glance the relation which the recent 
holds to the fossil Ovibos and the <u>enormous<\u> difference 
between that animal and the Sheep Buffalos Oxen 
and Bisons. From the <s>measurements of the<\s> first table 
the measurements of the fossil skulls described by D<sup>r<\sup> Pallas and Oseretzkowsky[?] have 
been purposely <s>omitted<\s> excluded because of <s>my<\s> the uncertainty as to 
whether they employed the French <s>or<\s> English or Russian 
inch, Cuvier taking one view and Sir John Richardson 
another. the terms of measurement of the Pelvis and three 
out of the four columns are taken from the works of Sir John Richardson so often 
referred to. <s>In the table<\s> 
In the table of measurements of teeth Number 1 is the anteroposterior 
<s>measurement<\s> extent, number 2 the anterotransverse <s>measurement<\s> diameter 
number 3 the posterotransverse and all are taken at the 
base. In the last lower molar there is an <s>addional<\s> additional 
transverse measurement for the additional lobe. <s>I<\s> 
In the measurements of long bones the following numbers 
are used throughout; <s>Number 1<\s> 
1.=  Maximum length. 
2 = Minimum circumference 
3 = transverse measurement of proximal articulation 
4 = vertical ditto. 
5 = transverse measurement of distal articulation. 
6 = vertical ditto.
